instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2796: What is 820-2796? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .
definitions.PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR: What is PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR? PPBUS_SW_LCDBKLT_PWR is PPBUS_G3H after it has passed through a backlight fuse and a transistor that allows power through when BKLT_PLT_RST_L and LCD_BKLT_EN are present. .
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_DIV: What is LCDBKLT_EN_DIV? LCDBKLT_EN_DIV must be low in order for the P channel MOSFET to have a lower voltage on the gate than is present on the source to allow backlight voltage to flow through the backlight circuit. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.A1370: What is A1370? A1370 is a model number for a 11 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2010, Mid 2011 with EMC 2393, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2796, 820-3024..

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2796</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2796</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: Check <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> and if that is ok then you first have to try a known good working LCD assembly.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2796</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
Duke, <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> (3.41V) is ok and i try two different LCD assembly.
Another advice?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2796</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: You need 5V coming through <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>, check if enable signal is there.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2796</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
<CHIP>U9000</CHIP>

Pin 1 - <SIGNAL>LCD_IG_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 0v
Pin 2 - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.30V
Pin 3 - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.30v
Pin 4 - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD_UF</SIGNAL> - 0V
Pin 5 - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SW_LCD_UF</SIGNAL> - 0V
Pin 6 - GND

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2796</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: if this is not chiming you have a much bigger problem. Are CPU & GPU vcore present? If the internal LCD is unplugged, can you get an image on external monitor?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2796</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
Louis, 
I tested it with external monitor and it worked perfectly.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2796</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: Are you testing this with an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> assembly? What is resistance to GND on pin 1 of <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2796</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JorgePayar, post: 2741"]Im not an engineer and I undestand 1.003 MΩ ( 1MΩ) :)[/QUOTE]

Just want to make a request that we try to understand what we don't understand before we make comments like this. Not a huge deal, but let's be good students here. I'm gonna go ahead and posit that if dukefawks says it doesn't make sense, it probably doesn't make sense. Diode mode doesn't measure resistance, it measures voltage drop to ground if the positive lead is on ground.
